abstract.para: This document is intended for customers of Cloud Feeds who want to submit a feed to be published through the Cloud Feeds engine.

listitem.para: Created first draft of the Cloud Feeds Publishers Guide

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: Rackspace Cloud Feeds enables customers on the public cloud to access near real-time usage and system events that can be used for analysis, monitoring, and automation. Internal customers also have the ability to publish feeds through the Cloud Feeds framework for usage by customers. This guide aims at providing guidelines for Cloud Feeds publishers to prepare feeds for publication through the Cloud Feeds engine.
To understand Cloud Feeds, users should know the following:

Apache Abdera (for more information, see Apache Abdera)

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: Cloud Feeds supports the publication of events that are collected in a feed. There is a specific format for the events, and you can have multiple types of events in a single feed.
Cloud Feeds uses AtomPub to publish different types of feeds. AtomPub is based on an HTTP transfer of Atom-formatted representations. The Atom format is documented in the Atom Syndication Format.

AtomHopper events must be defined using the Common Event Format (CEF). UMS (Usage Measurement Service) utilizes CEF for tracking purposes, but CEF can be also used for other events and by third-party event publishers. The Common Event Format supports versioning of the event and product nodes through the version attribute. This allows products to release new versions of their schema.
To read the official documentation for the Atom Syndication Format, see RFC 4287. For more information about AtomPub, visit http://atompub.org/.

section.title: Event types
section.para: Cloud Feeds supports the following event types.

Usage events
System events are published to notify subscribers about changes in their environments - a server has been provisioned, an IP address has been released, there is an error state in a VM, and so on.
User access events are generated when a user attempts to access a specific API (for example, if a user requests that a server be shut down).
These events are highly useful for troubleshooting and for compliance auditing.

section.title: Event format
section.para: Currently, Cloud Feeds supports Feeds in XML format. The feeds and events follow the Atom Syndication Format and the API adheres to the Atom Publication Protocol. A feed has the following structure:
The following table describes a description of each element in a feed:

tr.td: Generated by Cloud Feeds. This element is only present when reading the feeds. It includes information about the feed, such as how to navigate to the next "page" of events.
Contains information submitted by the publisher of the event and information generated by Cloud Feeds. Includes meta-information about the event, such as an ID, and categories the event should match.
Generated by the publisher. Contains information about the event that is not product-specific, such as the time/duration of the event, where the event occurred, etc.
Generated by the publisher. Contains product-specific information about the event, such as the server type, IP address, state, etc.

chapter.title: Event node
chapter.para: The Event node is the main element of a Cloud Feeds usage event entry.
The Event node contains the following elements:

para.programlisting: <event startTime="2014-07-14T22:19:52Z" endTime="2014-07-14T24:00:00Z" region="DFW" dataCenter="DFW1" type="USAGE" id="8d89673c-c989-11e1-895a-0b3d632a8a89" resourceId="3863d42a-ec9a-11e1-8e12-df8baa3ca440" tenantId="1234" version="2"> <cb-store:product version="1" serviceCode="CloudBackup" serverID="9445" storage="99992827882" resourceType="AGENT"/> </event>

section.para: The attributes in the event node are already pre-defined and cannot be changed. The event node consists of the following attributes:

tr.td: Specifies the start time of the event, the time format must be in ISO format: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSZ. The startTime is for the UTC time zone. startTime is inclusive, which means the event occurred starting at the startTime, not after.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
This attribute is required for events of type USAGE.

tr.td: Specifies the end time of the event, the time format must be: yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss.SSSZ. UTC, ISO Format end time. For an event of type EXIST, the startTime and endTime reflect the event duration for the resource instance. endTime is exclusive (i.e. the event occurred up to, but not during the endTime). endTime must occur after startTime.

listitem.para: This attribute is optional.
This attribute is required for events of type USAGE.
The startTime attribute must also be specified.
The event cannot span 24 hours

tr.td: Specifies the region in which the event is located. If this attribute is not specified, GLOBAL will be assumed. GLOBAL implies that the resource is region less. For a list of possible values, see Event node attributes.

chapter.title: Product node
chapter.para: The product node is located inside of an event node. The product node is custom and differs for every product. The product node identifies the product to which the feed refers. It also provides product-specific information and details about the resources. Product nodes are defined by using a sample product schema.
Following is an example of a product node:

para.programlisting: <sample:product serviceCode="EmailAppsMSService" version="1" key="(domain=5002_domain_2.com)|(service=5002_domain_2.com)" productType="lync" operation="UPDATE" status="COMPLETED" request="HTTP GET" response="200"> <sample:dependent key="(domain=1002_domain_200.com)|(service=1002_domain_100.com)"/> <sample:dependent key="(domain=2002_domain_200.com)|(service=2002_domain_200.com)"/> </sample:product>

section.title: XPathAssertion
section.para: XPath assertions nodes allow you to add further checks to your event using xPath assertions
For more information about XPath, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XPath.
An XPath test should evaluate to true() or false(). If false(), then the content of the element is returned in an error message.

The XPath context is the root product element by default. The context can be changed to the root of the entry via the scope attribute. The prefix 'p' is always bound to the product schema. If the context is entry then the prefix 'atom' is bound to the atom namespace and 'event' is bound to the event namespace. Finally, the prefix 'xs' is bound tho the XML Schema namespace.

note.para: When the scope is product, you cannot use .. to access parent elements. Use the entry scope instead.

section.para: Note that

tr.td: Specifies the scope of an XPath assertion. The scope determines what the context of the XPath assertion is. It can be either product or the entry. The default value for this attribute is product

td.para: When the scope is entry, the variables $entry, $event, and $product are defined, each pointing to the respective part of the message.

section.title: Versions
section.para: The event and product nodes are version-controlled. Cloud Feeds can support events containing different definitions for the event and product nodes simultaneously. This allows publishers to define a new event without breaking older events that have not yet adopted the new definition. The event and product versions are independent of each other.
You can define multiple versions for a specific product within a schema as shown in the following example:

For example, if you specify <event version="2"> then Cloud Feeds will apply different rules to startTime and endTime that if you specify <event version="1">. But you can use either version with any <product version="...">.

The duration type represents a length of time, such as 15 minutes; 2 hours; or 3 years, 7 months, 2 days, 8 hours, 32 minutes, and 12 seconds. This value does not have a specific beginning or end. For more information see the note below.
The date type represents a specific day in history such as September 26, 2005. Dates are written in the form CCYY-MM-DD. For example, September 26, 2005 is written as 2005-09-26.

The dateTime type represents a specific moment in history, such as 3:32 P.M., September 26, 2003. Date-time expressions are written in the form CCYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss. An optional time zone indicator in the form ±hh:mm may be suffixed to provide a time zone as an offset from Coordinated Universal Time (Greenwich Mean Time, UTC). For example, 2003-09-26T15:32:00-05:00 is 3:32 P.M., September 26, 2003 in the U.S. Eastern time zone. A Z can be used instead to indicate UTC: 1999-12-31T00:00:00Z.
Specifies a dateTime constraint to be in the UTC timezone. That is the timezone offset must be 0 OR the value must end with Z.

The time type represents a specific time of day on no particular day, such as 3:32 P.M. Times are written in the form ±hh:mm:ss.xxx using a 24-hour clock and as many fractions of a second as necessary. An optional time zone indicator in the form ±hh:mm may be suffixed to provide a time zone as an offset from Coordinated Universal Time (Greenwich Mean Time, UTC). For example, 15:32:00-05:00 is 3:32 P.M., in the U.S. Eastern time zone. A Z can be used instead to indicate UTC: 00:00:00Z.
Specifies a time constraint for the UTC timezone. The timezone offset must be 0 OR the value must end with Z.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of duration values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of date values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of dateTime values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of utcDateTime values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of time values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of utcTime values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gDay values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gMonth values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gYear values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gMonthDay values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of gMonthYear values.

Specifies an arbitrary sequence of bytes that has been encoded in ASCII characters using the Base-64 algorithm defined in RFC 2045. The letters A–Z and a–z, the digits 0–9, and the punctuation marks + and / are used to encode data according to an algorithm that maps four of these characters to three arbitrary bytes. The equal sign is used to pad data at the end if necessary.
The anyURI type indicates a Uniform Resource Identifier. This includes not only Uniform Resource Locators (URLs), but also Uniform Resource Names (URNs). Both relative and absolute URLs are allowed.

Specifies a universally unique identifier in its canonical form: 32 hexadecimal digits, displayed in five groups separated by hyphens, in the form 8-4-4-4-12 for a total of 36 characters (32 digits and four hyphens). For example: 7eadda6a-9f3e-11e1-9ef4-77b6922f8866.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of anyURI values.
Specifies a whitespace-separated list of UUID values.

note.para: Durations are represented using the ISO-8601 standard format PnYnMnDTnHnMnS. nY specifies the number of years, nM the number of months, nD the number of days, nH the number of hours, nM the number of minutes, and nS the number of seconds. The number of years, months, days, hours, minutes, and seconds are all specified as nonnegative integers. The number of seconds is a decimal number with as many places after the decimal point as necessary. For example, in this format, 3 years, 7 months, 2 days, 8 hours, 32 minutes, and 12 seconds is written as P3Y7M2DT8H32M12S. Any values that are zero can be omitted. A duration of 2 years and 2 minutes can be written as P2YT2M. If there are no hours, minutes, or seconds, then the T is omitted. A duration of two years is written as P2Y. A leading minus sign before the P indicates a negative duration.
